Award.AwardTitle: The AQUARIUS (Air QUAlity Research In the western US) Workshop; Salt Lake City, Utah; April 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports a workshop, "The AQUARIUS (Air QUAlity Research In the western US) Workshop," to be held in Salt Lake City, Utah for two days in 2019. The goal of the workshop is to bring together experts to discuss and develop plans for a future aircraft campaign to investigate wintertime particulate matter (PM) in the mountain basins of the Western U.S. The outcome of the project will be a white paper outlining the scope and plan for a future aircraft and ground-based field campaign. Early career scientists will be given priority for travel support,

Despite the now extensive knowledge of atmospheric chemistry and the formation of PM, existing models do not reproduce pollutant concentrations in several air basins in the Western US. The chemistry in these regions is significantly impacted by the boundary layer meteorology which can confine the pollution mixture below the height of surrounding terrain for an extended period. During the PCAPs local and regional emissions accumulate and age, changing the composition of the PM. While previous field studies have investigated the boundary and atmospheric chemistry individually, no studies have collected a suite of data needed to assess their interactions. Additionally, because precursors of PM are often emitted with GHGs, both will be impacted by GHG mitigation plans. The goal of this workshop is to bring together research leaders and young scientists in the boundary-layer meteorology, atmospheric chemistry, and urban carbon cycle communities to develop joint and complementary science objectives for a large measurement campaign in the western U.S. Discussions will focus on the following topics: 1) the impact of agricultural emissions, residential wood combustion, and volatile chemical products on wintertime air quality; 2) the data and parameterizations needed to improve models of wintertime PCAPs; 3) the impact of inter-basin transport and vertical stratification of PCAPs; 4) the emission ratios between PM precursors and GHGs; and 5) how GHG mitigation actions might affect wintertime air quality. The broader impacts of this project will be the development of a document to guide development of a future field campaign focused on addressing these scientific goals. Additionally, the workshop organizers have existing relationships with state and local air quality management agencies and the scientific knowledge and data obtained in this effort would be used to address current challenges within air quality management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Particulate matter (PM) negatively affects human health, visibility and climate. PM concentrations have declined broadly across the U.S. as a result of emissions reductions. However, in several topographic basins in the western U.S., wintertime PM concentrations have decreased only modestly. Multiday wintertime meteorological stagnation events occur in these basins during which air movement and pollution ventilation are confined to shallow layers below the height of the surrounding terrain; such events are termed persistent cold air pools (PCAPs). Local and regional emissions accumulate during PCAPs, and subsequent chemical transformations of these emissions form PM. The limited improvement in wintertime air quality in these basins suggests both that current mitigation strategies may not be effectively targeting the appropriate precursor emissions and that there is a gap in understanding of how the unique boundary layer meteorology and complex chemical processes interact to produce these elevated PM conditions. In addition, mitigation strategies for PM precursors have implications for co-emitted greenhouse gases (GHGs), which many cities are also working to reduce. It is vital to understand linkages between atmospheric chemistry, boundary layer meteorology, and GHG gas mitigation plans, and how these will impact air quality now and in the future.

The AQUARIUS (Air QUAlity Research in the western US) Workshop, which was jointly funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) was held in September 2019 in Salt Lake City, Utah with the purpose of determining the current state of the science with respect to wintertime particulate pollution problems in the Western US. The workshop focused on the state of the science and how a future aircraft campaign proposed for the winter of 2022/2023 could best investigate wintertime PM in mountain basins of the western U.S. The specific goals of the workshop were to identify the current state of knowledge surrounding chemical processes of wintertime PM formation, the meteorological conditions that affect PM formation, distribution and transport, as well as the chemical species such as GHGs that are co-emitted with PM precursor emissions.                                                                                                                      

Over 125 scientists from academic, state and federal agencies across the United States and the world (representing 50 institutions and 5 countries) came together during the AQUARIUS workshop the determine the current state of the science with respect to wintertime particulate pollution problems in the Western US.                                                                                                                                   

The AQUARIUS workshop successfully identified the research priorities of the future proposed aircraft study, including atmospheric chemistry, the meteorology of inversions, and the measurements needed to understand emissions sources across urban and rural areas. The workshop was held over 2 days and split evenly between invited speakers and small-group breakout sessions. Several key topic areas that were addressed during the workshop included emissions and chemistry, particulate chemistry, meteorological and chemical coupling, and greenhouse gases.

The NSF funding for this workshop supported travel to the meeting for 25 attendees who would not have been able to otherwise attend, including students and early-career scientists.

 The workshop attendees are currently composing a white paper on the science needs for the upcoming AQUARIUS aircraft and ground-based study that will be made publicly available in 2020. A summary of the workshop outcomes will also be presented in a peer-reviewed article to be submitted in 2020 to the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society. The proposal for the publication in BAMS has been submitted and approved. 

A list of meeting attendees, meeting agenda, and other pertinent information can be found on the AQUARIUS website:

https://atmos.utah.edu/aquarius/
